title: Domain Adaptation for Mobile Robot Navigation

author: David Bradley, Robotics Institute, School of Computer Science, Carnegie Mellon University

segmentation: Hi so as the as Francesco said, I'm going to be talking about some domain adaptation work that Drew and I did on a mobile robot navigation problem, and in particular the application that will be talking.
Route is outdoor offroad autonomous driving.

Algorithm that we're using here we have a preprocessing stage where first we collect unlabeled data from logs in the training environment and from that we compute a distribution estimate of the probability of seeing a particular feature vector given that we're in the training environment.

Now we do the same thing for the test environment, using just unlabeled data that we collect continuously and that gives us a distribution estimate there and then by reweighting all the examples in the training set by this probability of seeing the example in the test environment divided by the probability of seeing it in the training environment, that gives us a more relevant training set that we can then use to train our classifier.
And so this is just an important sampling technique, an basically what it's doing is it's trying to minimize the expected error on the test set by reweighting the training set.
So if we rewrite the expected error on the test set, we can add in this multiplication by 1.
Here we're going to multiply by the probability example in the training set divided by the example the training set, and then we rearrange and then that gives us this important weighting factor.
Now an interesting thing to note here.
Is that this piece star indicates that these are the probabilities of labeled examples in the training set and what we actually have is unlabeled examples.
So we.
We have two main assumptions here.
The first one is that the conditional probability in the training and test set stays the same.

But the second one that can actually be pretty quick, tricky to deal with in practice is that we want the probability that we've labeled an example in the training set to equal the probability that we've labeled it in the test set, and so that gets to be kind of hard to enforce in practice.
And we also investigated two different models of doing the density estimation.

The first one was found a 2 dimensional subspace, an FTA Gaussian mixture model in that subspace, and the second one was to replace that 'cause I mean, there were really estimating 2 high dimensional distributions.
We want to replace that with a single probabilistic classifier and so we can do that.
It was an excellent paper last years NIPS that I saw that showed that this ratio of two probability distributions could just be replaced by a single probabilistic.
Pacifier.

The green healthy vegetation.
And so, more quantitatively, it turned out that the Gaussian mixture model didn't work very well on average, but using this logistic regression trick give us much better performance.

And what this is showing is it's the percent of that gap between training on the other environments and training on the current environment that the robots running in, and so we can actually get a pretty significant section of that gap with this technique.
And the logistic regression is also a lot more consistent across different training environments, probably because it's not trying to do as much work with estimating the two distributions.
And another interesting thing to note about this is that this is not just simply rearranging the distribution of the output target classes that we're trying to get to.
What this is showing is the percentage of rigid examples in the training set and the sorted by how well this technique improved performance on the environment.
